metadata.notes: The text is fragmentary (X indicates damaged/missing signs). "i" likely refers to "i3" (oil) which is common in Ur III administrative texts. "ukim" may relate to binding or fastening. Due to the missing initial sign(s), the full context is unclear.

This is a standard administrative formula from Ur III period texts. "kišib" (kicib) means "seal" or "sealed document," and "Ur-nigar" is a personal name. The phrase indicates that this document was sealed by or under the authority of a person named Ur-nigar.
kin = work/labor, -bi = its (possessive suffix), sar = a unit of area measurement. This is a typical administrative notation recording the amount of work done, measured in sar units.

The term "u" typically refers to workdays in Ur III administrative texts. "Sag-nigura" appears to be a location name, likely referring to a storehouse or administrative building. The compound "sag-nig2-gur11-ra" literally means "head of the storehouse" or could be a place name associated with storage facilities.

predictions.reference: year : “ The silver-chair of Enlil was fashioned . ”
predictions.prediction: year: "The golden throne of Enlil was fashioned."

metadata.translation: year: "The golden throne of Enlil was fashioned."
metadata.notes: This is a year name formula (mu = year). "ku" represents gold (kug), "guza" is throne, "enlila" is the genitive form of Enlil (the chief deity of Nippur), and "badim" (ba-dim2) means "was fashioned/made." Year names commemorating the creation of divine furniture were common in Ur III administrative texts.

predictions.reference: booked out of ( the account of ) Ahuni ,

metadata.notes: Standard Ur III administrative formula. "ki ... -ta" means "from (a person)", where Ahuni is the source/supplier. "ba-zi" is a common verbal form meaning "was disbursed/expended" or indicating the recipient who received the goods.

The term "u" typically means "day" in Sumerian administrative texts. "muscbian" or "muš-bi-an" likely refers to nighttime or "at night" (muš = night, bi = its, an = locative marker). This phrase appears to be a temporal marker indicating when something occurred.

This follows the standard Ur III administrative formula "ki [personal name]-ta" meaning "from [personal name]". The structure parallels examples like "ki abasagata" (from Abbasaga) and "ki amarcubata" (from Amar-šuba). Budu is a known Sumerian personal name.

This is the name of the famous legendary Sumerian king of Uruk, hero of the Epic of Gilgamesh. The name in Sumerian is written as "Bilgames" or "Gilgamesh" and means approximately "the ancestor is a hero/young man."

GAN refers to a field measure (iku). "ug" means death/to die. "urgigir" is a personal name (Ur-gigir). This likely records a field allocation or transaction related to someone named Ur-gigir who has died, possibly indicating inheritance or reassignment of land.

Šara-zida is a personal name meaning "Šara is righteous." The pattern matches other entries where NUMB precedes a personal name, typically indicating an allocation or quantity for that person.
The text contains only "X" which represents a damaged or illegible portion of the original cuneiform tablet. This is a standard notation in Sumerian transliteration for unreadable signs.

This is a personal name followed by a profession. "Akala" is a proper name, and "ašgab" (acgab) is the Sumerian term for leather worker/leatherworker. This follows the common Ur III administrative pattern of listing individuals with their professions.

giri = "via" or "conveyed by" (indicates the intermediary/agent); cuecdar = personal name Šu-Ešdar (meaning "Hand of Ešdar/Ištar"); sagi = cup-bearer (a common profession in Ur III administrative texts)

"igi" means "before/in the presence of" (commonly used in witness clauses), "dumu" means "son", and "ursuen" is a personal name meaning "servant of the moon god Suen". This is likely part of a witness formula in an administrative or legal document.

metadata.notes: This appears to be a measurement text describing dimensions. "ninda" is a unit of length (about 6 meters), "kuš" (kuc) is a cubit measurement. "gid" means long/length, "dagal" means wide/width, and "bur" here likely refers to depth or thickness. This type of dimensional notation is common in Ur III administrative texts for describing fields, canals, or structures.

metadata.notes: This is a standard Sumerian measurement description. 'ninda' is a unit of length (approximately 6 meters), 'kuš' (cubit, approximately 50 cm) is another length unit. 'gid' means 'long/length', 'dagal' means 'wide/width', and 'bur' typically means 'depth/deep' in dimensional contexts. This appears to be describing the dimensions of a field, canal, or structure.

Standard Ur III administrative notation for measuring semolina (dabin). "sila" is a capacity measure, "gur" is a larger unit (approximately 300 liters). The pattern follows typical grain/flour measurement formulas found in economic texts.

predictions.reference: year after : “ The house Puzris-Dagan was erected . ”

metadata.translation: year following (the year): "The house of Puzriš-Dagan was built."
metadata.notes: This is a standard Ur III year name formula. "mu us2-sa" indicates "year following" a previous named year. "e...ba-du3" is the common construction for "house/temple was built." Puzriš-Dagan (modern Drehem) was a major administrative center during the Ur III period.

še-numun is a common Sumerian compound meaning "seed barley" or "barley for sowing." It appears frequently in Ur III administrative texts recording agricultural allocations. The term combines še (barley) with numun (seed).

This follows the common Ur III administrative pattern seen in similar entries (examples 35, 75, etc.) where a number precedes a personal name, typically indicating an allocation of wool measured in mana. Lu-Enkidu is a Sumerian personal name meaning "Man of Enkidu."

Standard Ur III personal name formula. "u" functions as a conjunction "and"; "Lugal-baba" is a theophoric personal name meaning "king is (my) father"; "dumu" means "son of"; "Ur-Lamma" is another personal name meaning "servant of Lamma (a protective deity)".

predictions.prediction: NUMB minas NUMB shekels of silver

metadata.translation: NUMB minas NUMB shekels of silver
metadata.notes: Standard Ur III administrative weight measurement formula. "mana" = mina (unit of weight), "gin" = shekel (1/60 of a mina), "ku" = kù-babbar (silver). This is a typical notation for recording silver amounts in economic texts.
cunigin is the standard Sumerian term for "total" (šunigin), commonly used in administrative texts. gamun refers to cumin, a spice frequently mentioned in Ur III period economic documents.

This is a Sumerian personal name. The name can be analyzed as "lugal" (king) + "nig" (thing) + "lagar" (priest/cult servant) + "e" (ergative suffix or part of name). It appears as a proper noun, likely referring to a person in an administrative context.

The Sumerian word "šag" (written as "caga" in transliteration, where "c" represents "š") means "heart" or "interior/middle." It is a common noun in Sumerian texts appearing in various administrative and literary contexts.

predictions.reference: NUMB diš- ( worker ) : Lu-Nanna , his son ,

metadata.notes: This follows common Ur III administrative text patterns. "lunanna" is a personal name (Lu-Nanna, meaning "man of Nanna/the moon god"), and "dumuni" is "dumu" (son) + possessive suffix "-ani" (his), indicating a kinship relationship.

This is a personal name composed of the divine king's name "Šulgi" (the second king of the Third Dynasty of Ur) combined with "ḫazir" (meaning "overseer" or "inspector"). The name translates roughly to "Šulgi is my overseer" or could simply be rendered as the proper name "Šulgi-ḫazir".

This appears to be a personal name. "ur" is a common Sumerian name element meaning "man of" or "servant of", and "šara" (written as "cara/sara") is a deity name. The initial "uc" may be a variant writing of "ur". The name Ur-Šara appears in other examples in the corpus (e.g., "urcarake" = "Ur-Šara weighed").

The text appears to be a designation for a group of workers or personnel. The "me" suffix typically indicates plurality ("they are" or marking a group). "ugIL" is unclear - it may be a damaged or abbreviated form of a title or profession. It could potentially be related to "ugula" (foreman/overseer) combined with another element, or a personal/professional designation. The reading is uncertain due to the unusual orthography.

This is a Sumerian personal name meaning "Lord of the month" or "King of the month", composed of lugal (king/lord) + iti (month) + da (locative/genitive suffix). It appears as a proper noun/personal name in administrative texts.
